postcontent: h&r self-loading pistol was manufactured during the period 1910-1914,under agreement with webley & scott of birmingham england, and it is in fact, the webley .25 "hammerless" model of 1909.patents were taken out in the US in 1907 and 1909, principally covering the use of twin recoil springs, and the H&R differs from the webley in many ways. the webley is hammerless in name only,since it used an internal hammer, and the H&r lockwork was rather different than the webley, probably as a matter of manufacturing convenience.more obvious is the shaping of the barrel and slide; in the webley pattern the slide is open topped with a bridge carrying the front sight.as a result the barrel is slender so the bridge can pass over it on recoil. the H&R model uses an open topped slide without a bridge,and the barrel rear section is built up to continue the contours of the slide;there are no rear sights fitted. the external contours of the H&R are more generally radiussed than those of the webley, and the grips are fitted in a different manner. it was believed that there was little demand for the .25 model and few were made.. H&R also produced a .32 model which, while based on webley practice, was not a counterpart of any webley and scott model. it was 'hammerless' ( i.e internal hammer)model with open topped slide and extended barrel, and a short grip safety at the rear of the butt. it also used a coil spring recoil spring above the bolt, instead of the webley v-spring system. this model appeared shortly befor the first world war, and continued to me made into the early 1920's. this one is clean as a whistle with minor original holster wear , no rust, no pitting. shine in bore strong rifleing. perfect grips 8+1 capacity.

title: For Sale:  H&K P7M8 - Outstanding
postcontent:
This is the H&K P7M8 you have been wishing for.  All matched numbers, three H&K magazines, night sites and standard sites, original cleaning rod and brush-unused, OEM plastic box (not matching SN#), and owners manual.

For those who have never had the privilege to shoot a P7, it is unlike any other handgun ever made.  A squeeze of the grip cocks the gun, while releasing that squeeze de-cocks it as well.  When the slide locks open, the same squeeze releases the slide lock.  One button push allows field stripping that anyone could do in the dark.

The P7 format is no longer in production.  Quite honestly, few law enforcement agencies or militaries can afford to equip their troops with such a well engineered sidearm.  (If wrong please advise) this handgun is the only handgun produced with a gas recoil, retarded inertia bolt cycling system.  Simply put this pistol, like high powered rifles, is a gas operated, semi-auto.

Since investing in this piece, I have learned that the original P7 was called PSP (Polizei selbstladen Pistole) and had its magazine release on the bottom of the butt.

The P7M8 was made for the American market, in the 9x19mm, 8 round with an eight round magazine.  A later 9x19mm version, the P7M13 had a 13 round magazine.  The same format was also used in .40 cal S&W and 10 mm.  A stainless steel model was also produced for Americans, who are known worldwide to not properly maintaining their firearms.  The P7 has made it into several TV shows and movies, utilized when the shooter was a person of wealth or distinction.  

The P7 is an all steel handgun, rock-solid in the hand.  Utilizing the fore mentioned squeeze cock function, the trigger trips at approx 2 lb pull, too light for any other duty handgun that does not have the unique safety features.  Tipping the scales at 27.5 oz empty, follow up shots are incredibly quick and accurate.

For the 10% southpaw population or any serious handgunner that knows he must be able to effective use your weapon with either hand, the P7M8 is completely ambidextrous.  Every function in performed exactly the same by lefties and righties, including the dual sided Americanized magazine release.  This is the weapon that range instructors can only dream of for basic handgun training.

End of history lesson for today.  As mentioned above, this beauty comes with three OEM H&K blued steel, eight shot magazines, each showing minor bluing wear.  Most P7’s you see in the States have only one magazine.  

The night sites have died.  It would be my guess that H&K in Sterling, VA, would replace the night sites without charge.  When you are one of the five finest firearms manufactures in the world, you treat your customers very well.

This pistol is immaculate, only very minor holster wear on the sharp corners on the front of the slide.  No drop dings.  The grips are perfect, what a beautiful piece!

Round count, who cares?  European designed firearms originate where terrorism happens every day.  Their troops fire thousands of rounds yearly in training.  The average American design weapon would rattle into pieces in no time under those conditions. 
There are proofing stamps on the right side of the slide and frame are BWB 318.  This is the BMI or Federal Ministry of Interior symbol, the bird is the Bundesadler (Federal Eagle).  The German Govt. does their own proofing and therefore does not bear the staghorn proofmark on items for commercial consumption.   I am told that this pistol was used the Bundesgrenzschutz, roughly the equivlent of our Border Patrol.

Near the proofing, there is a place where the insignia of the Bundesgrenzschutzn was removed prior to entering the civilian market. 

Now down to nickels and dimes.  
The firm cash price is $2,000.  
I will try to reduce the sting.  I will take in trade:  a carry worthy P7M13, US face silver or hallmarked gold or silver at spot melt.

Face to face transaction in Columbus, Ohio, or shipped to your FFL on your dime.

Many thanks to everyone who sent me tidbits of info on the P7.  I learned a lot, hopefully others will learn, also.

Bill Good
